column1: Call came in and Informing of important message and to press a number to be transferred. I was then informed that my identity has been used to purchase a phoneline and the number was also used to scam money from people. I should have noticed the red flags when they asked for my name and phone number. Anyway
column2: my my call was suddenly passed to the person's manager. The manager repeated the problem and that it is paramount I contact china shanghai police department within 2 hours as it was a serious offence. After I asked for more details and how to reach the China Police Station. He offered to transfer the call. That was when I know I am in a middle of a scam. I hung up but they kept calling back for more than 10 times.Editor's Note: If an incoming call has a "+" prefix
column3: pls do not pick up if you are not expecting overseas phone calls as this is mostly likely be a scam call. Do not hand over your personal details over the phone without verification.

column1: I was called by Singtel officer asking details about how internet service is slow and then blame it on network sharing. Then he was joined by another officer from CSA ( cyber security agency)
column2: they both intimated me to reveal all the details about my banks and then they tricked me to transfer SGD 45000 ( USD 33000) to some person in HK. I have reported the case with police and investigation is underway also i have asked the bank to stop transaction. For this purpose i am not sharing any further details. I am reporting this to alert the community.

column1: I received 2 scam calls from someone claimed that they are from amazon. Right from the beginning I knew those were scam calls but i played along as i wanted to know what kind of tricks they are using. 1) first call was an Indian accent guy who said i have made a purchase for a laptop that costs $3000. I asked him name of person who made the order. he told me michael William. i asked him do I sound like Michael (I am female). he said yes. i repeated do i sound like a guy. he hung off. my caller id showed he called from a mobile number. i called back that number. it was a valid number but nobody answered the call. the next day i received a missed call. when I returned the call
column2: a lady answered. I told her i got a missed call from her number
column3: she said she also received a missed call from my number. 2) second call was also from an Indian accent guy. this time the caller said someone from Germany had just made a purchase for a $5000 MacBook using my amazon account. he asked me do i want to approve or decline the purchase. i asked him what do i need to do to approve or decline. he said if approve
column4: then i have to make payment from my bank account. I told him i prefer to pay by credit card. he said there is already a pending credit card payment. i then asked for the last 4 digits of the credit card number. he said he will email me the details and i have to enter 6 pin number to open it. i refused and insisted he tells me over the phone. he lost his patience and said to me "you just come down to amazon office to give me a bxxx job and I will tell you the number". he wasn't even able to tell me amazon office address nor phone number but instead asking me to google for it. This scammer also spoofed a mobile number
column5: so i called back that number
column6: it turned out to be an invalid number

column1: I fell prey to the online purchase scam recently (about 2 days ago) as my wife shared a link on a super cheap robot vacuum cleaner that only cost $39. At first

column5: you just have to double and triple check and alert yourself that it is a scam. The total lost was $39. to me it's a big lesson learnt to not fall into such prey again and warn my families and friends.

column1: Received a text message saying that they are license money lender and also with a Whatsapp link to enquire with them. Gave them my personal particular such as ic photo
column2: payslip and contact number. before the loan was approve
column3: they said their company procedure was to start a trail loan. at this point of time i really did not realise i am dealing with unlicensed money lender. they proceed to transfer me the trail loan amount and 5 days later when i inform them i want to clear the amount and cancel my loan
column4: they say they got no bank account to clear off my loan. however only defer of loan is allow. at this point of time I realise i am dealing with unlicensed money lender yet i was afraid as they had my particular so i gave in. after deferring the loan for another 5 days
column5: they told me the same reason again. after transferring them a total of 4 times
column6: all these transfer to them
column7: it was always different bank account. until one day they text me and said their company are choosing new customer to borrow our bank account to transfer money to their supplier. i really couldn't take the pressure and stress. i proceed to the NPC to file a report and block the contact. but things didn't end here
column8: they contacted me using other number
column9: threatening and harassing me. from their tone of reply
column10: they were pissed off
column11: and start raising and shouting using the voice message. The whole experience has been traumatizing.Editor's Note: Please note that all licensed moneylenders are NOT allowed to advertise online (including social media)
column12: through phone call
column13: SMS or messaging apps. They are also not allowed to approve loans remotely but only at the registered office locations. Some scammers / unlicensed moneylenders will impersonate licensed moneylenders by using their name
column14: licence number to set up fake websites. If you wish to get in touch with a licensed moneylender
column15: only get touch through the contact details shown in this list: https://rom.mlaw.gov.sg/information-for-borrowers/list-of-licensed-moneylenders-in-singapore/

column1: My wife is pregnant with another baby
column2: and with the debts that the family have
column3: she wanted to help lighten financial load of family. She resorted online for part time jobs but was subsequently scammed online up to $120
column4: 000 after being asked to get more loans to put in more money in order to get her money back. She never got back her money. After this incident
column5: she feels shameful
column6: anxiety attacks and having suicidal thoughts for what she did. She blames herself for being na√Øve and stupid and no longer trust her ability to discern right from wrong.What happened Pregnant with a baby and family debts
column7: my wife decided to google part time jobs online. A man named James offered her a part time job online to earn some money by buying things in his ecommerce platform just to boost his order numbers. And subsequently he promised to return her money with 10% commission. The orders were small initially at $3. She bank transfer $3 and she did receive a return $3.10 commission. Throughout the day
column8: she trusted the business (Volusion.live) and slowly transferred up to $4000 to James and received commission from it around $200 at the payout timing 9pm. Next day
column9: the company (Volusion.Live) approached her again. After gaining trust from my wife
column10: she was asked to make a purchase of $5000 of item. After making the bank transfer
column11: the company assured my wife that the payout will only be made at 9pm. She was also placed into a group chat where there many other part timers (fake accounts) doing this and they also assured her that it is not a scam and it is legit. They subsequently used time running out tricks and scares to make my wife send more money in if not she will not receive her money back. The order amounts subsequently escalated to 20k+ where she realised
column12: she does not have enough cash to fund the orders. The scammers and the part timers then suggested to loan from banks
column13: families and friends and mentioned that it is normal to do that and that everyone doing this is loaning money. They promised to return her money once she made the orders. She borrowed like around $100k from banks
column14: friends and family to fund her account and it was only after that she realised that these scammers will never give back her money that she decided to inform her husband and called the police.

column1: I met Harry Ronnie on a dating app and we continue on whatsapp
column2: planned to meet up but before we meet up he said that his company is sending him to Malaysia but once he‚Äôs back we‚Äôll meet and spend time together. He said his Scotland bank account got locked and he needs to access it to get funds for the job he‚Äôs doing in Malaysia for Petronas. He said he needed a SG simcard for it but since he‚Äôs in Malaysia he‚Äôs asks me a favour to buy a sim card and send it to him. I was blinded by his sweet words and want to help I bought and sent it via FedEx. He said he needs to do top up. After doing the top up he said that its not working and asked me if it‚Äôs okay for me to lend some money which I said no. He called and got mad then said he‚Äôs just going to borrow money from his colleague Kim Wang and if it can be deposit to my bank account so I can send it to him because he really wants to finish his work asap as the covid there is high. He said the money is for him to buy materials for work and expenses in Malaysia. After transferring the money deposited to my account I received a call from the bank telling me that my online banking has been disabled and that a deposited cash to my account has been reported as a fraud. I was confused on what‚Äôs happening so I told the bank I will first check what‚Äôs happening. Harry Ronnie said that his colleague Wang didn‚Äôt reported anything and that he will ask Wang to go to the bank. He suddenly said his colleague transferred another money to my account and that I should send it to him via WU because he needed it to settle his workers payment. There‚Äôs an issue with the WU that I was not able to send him the money. He called
column3: shouted and accused me of lying to him and taking interest on his money. This is also when I feel pressured and broke down crying because he‚Äôs accusing me. To prove to him that I‚Äôm not lying I borrow money from a colleague so the money can be sent to him. We got okay after the money has been transferred to him and he said that he‚Äôll come back to Singapore by Sunday and asked if I can send him cash because he still needs to settle his workers payment and I told him that I can‚Äôt send him any cash. He showed me a CIMB cheque and a letter that he needs to pay the worker‚Äôs first before he can travel back to Singapore. I know it‚Äôs too late but this is when I realized that I‚Äôm being scammed so I called the police and ask what to do next as I‚Äôm really confused.

column1: Got to know the person through Facebook. She will try to tell you about her life

column1: Got to know this guy from Facebook dating app. Only after chatting for a day or a day or two
column2: they will advance super quickly to ask you to chat on another platform
column3: like WhatsApp or telegram. told me that he is a Singaporean
column4: but was raised in the us. Father is like a nomad
column5: always moving around countries to countries. First to the UK
column6: then to the us and settled down there. He will share with you sob stories of how his parents died in a car accident few years back
column7: his fiancee broke up with him just before their wedding because she found out she is at the final stage of some cancer
column8: does not have any family members around because their relationship was not good. Only have 1 best friend who is currently serving the army in Afghan. He is an oil rig consultant. Works offshore
column9: and operates independently. Got himself a place here in Singapore. Told me that he has to travel to Houston for a submit conference
column10: even screenshot to show you the content of his last minute invitation. Told me he has an oil rig contract to fulfil in Ukraine in 2 weeks‚Äô time. Things started escalating quickly
column11: he will just suddenly and randomly drop you a random WhatsApp call
column12: and try to guilt trip you that you are avoiding him. And shortly after chatting
column13: they will say they love you and ask you to be his partner. Even if they haven't seen you. Their reasoning is
column14: they know that you are the one for them. i requested for a video call. But he gave quite a number of ridiculous reasoning like he can't do video calls because of where he is. But promise to call me on a certain day when he goes back to Baltimore. Scammer will try to sweet talk you and make you believe in him. Once he got to Ukraine for his contract
column15: 2 weeks later
column16: he will call or send you a text that his mud pump is faulty and he needed financial help. I was sceptical at first
column17: but the way they speak to you
column18: is so believable that you will think is true. And he sounded really desperate that all i wanted was to help
column19: which I eventually did. And reasons for him asking for more money became more ridiculous
column20: like paying his supplier and his workers
column21: or having no money to eat
column22: and needing to take a private jet back to the USA
column23: so he can pay everyone that he has asked to borrow money from. When i suggested to him to take a commercial flight
column24: another stupid reason came out again
column25: and he will guilt trip you by saying you don't understand what he is going through. This was the time when i started to suspect that i got scammed
column26: and made a police report.

column1: Please be careful when meeting people on dating apps such as tinder
column2: cimb etc.The scammers will always sweet talk you and say how in love they are with you when you have never met them in person. They will always give excuses when you say you want to meet. They will start introducing you to investment schemes such as lottery apps which they found loopholes and have been earning money from the app which no one is aware.The usual tactic they use is to entice you with small wins first and let you enjoy the gains for a period.Then they will start to brainwash you to put more money in so that the returns you get will be higher. Next is tell you there is a once in a lifetime promotion. The more money you put in
column3: the more bonus money you will get in return. He will take the lead first and show you that he has put in all his money in and left you to pump in the money to enjoy the promotion. He will pressurize you with deadline
column4: if the money is not pumped in within certain time
column5: all your existing money in the account will be lost.Please be more alert when someone start talking to you about investment or money when you have never met the person. These scammers have well thought out plan in mind to use on their victims. Editor's Note: Investors are reminded to do their own due diligence before investing. Always do a "Ask. Check. Confirm" to find out more about a scheme to minimise the possibility of getting scammed. More resource on how to look out for investment scams can be found here: https://www.moneysense.gov.sg/articles/2018/10/how-to-spot-an-investment-scam

column8: bank officer

column1: I received a call from the mobile number 9320019? on 15 Sep 2021 (Weds) at around 3:50pm. When I answered the call
column2: I heard a voice message purporting to be from the "Singapore high court" informing me that i had a "summons" that "had not been processed" and inviting me to press "9" for more information. Upon pressing "9"
column3: I was attended to by a man who sounded like someone of Chinese ethnicity. I explained to the man that I had been redirected to him after hearing a voice message (the contents of which I relayed to him). The man asked for my summons number; I replied that I did not know. The man then asked for my identification number; after supplying him with fake information
column4: I revealed to him that I was going to report his number to the authorities as the call was obviously a scam call. His response was simply to tell me to "please go ahead and report me" before hanging up. At all times during the call described above
column5: I put on a fake accent and was fully aware that the call was not legitimate. I am just sharing this experience to raise awareness.

column1: Scammer called claiming he‚Äôs from Amazon. Ask if I have authorized a transaction for SGD2412. I said no and he said he will stop the transaction. He said that it is no use and the transaction will go through unless he verifies my email address. My husband asked him to send 2FA to my email address and told him off before he hung up on him. This guy has a heavy Indian accent and the number shows local line number with a prefix of +65.

column1: I got a call from someone claiming to be from amazon.com. Said that there is a suspicious transaction on my account and asked me for my email to verify I'm the amazon user. column1: At first

Some will use licensed moneylenders' license number or create fake websites under their name. Please only contact licensed moneylenders through the contact details found on this website: List Of Licensed Moneylenders In Singapore (mlaw.gov.sg). Licensed moneylenders are also not allowed to approve loans remotely

How it works is that I have to help the person who referred me to grab 40 orders first then go to my account and finish 40 orders before i can withdraw money. Sometimes i will have to recharge/top up the account with my own money by contacting their 'customer service' (+65 8912 4534) which random bank accounts will be given each day or will change every now and then. column3: all top up and commission will be sent to my bank account. I only did this for a day but it was already very sketchy. On the first day i earned $70+
column4: $130+ if inclusive of my top-up amount

I see some other agents in the group chat recharging 1k+ into their account but I'm not convinced. I read up on some scams on order grabbing and am still not sure if this is a legitimate business. Please beware of random job offers especially if it requires a deposit from your own account.

column1: I was approached on Carousell pertaining my watch listings at around 3pm on 20th August 2021. The person asked for my number and texted me on whatsapp thereafter. column2: people will still try to negotiate a couple of hundreds off
column3: but he did not and even said that he will round the sum up for me. He claimed that he is not in Singapore and that he wants to buy a watch for his brother as a present. Hence he will make the transfer online and ask a courier to pick up the watches. I felt that something was not right so I went in and checked his profile on Carousell and the account was created couple of hours ago before he first approached me for the watches. But because it was Singapore contact number (+65 8401 8902?
column4: I went ahead and still chatted with him since there is a chance he might be a real buyer. He then proceeded to ask for personal information pertaining to my bank account number

column6: he wanted to deal with me the next day
column7: on 21st August 2021 morning instead. Around 10pm on 20th August
column8: which is the day itself
column9: I noticed that Carousell has already banned the account - so I thought I am right and that the scammer won't contact me anymore. But on the 21st August morning
column10: the scammer continued to text me on Whatsapp and asked whether if we can deal by 4pm that day. I replied yes
column11: saying that so long as I can sight the funds

column1: I was looking for personal loan in the internet. I came across a website lendin? bee and to input the loan amount i needed and my contact. Then
column2: I received a Whatsapp from the person called eric and told me about the loan process and repayment plan and send me a contract related to the loan after i send over my details such as ic
column3: bank statement and payslip. He told me to pay stamping fee 385 and admin fees 385 total 770 which I did. Then I received another invoice from different person from different number 8895908? to pay another 450 for account opening
column4: if I never pay the loan approval will b on hold that‚Äôs when i realized that this must a scam and when to website to look for the company again there‚Äôs a page which is different and I read about the important notice regards to scam. I read and understand that company won‚Äôt ask for advanced payment before any loan approval. I immediately made a police report and call the bank to report as well. Its my stupidity to fall into this without calling the company to check and fall into their trap. Hopefully this ends here from this scammers. Lesson learnt. Editor's Note: Please note that unlicensed moneylenders can impersonate as licensed moneylenders by creating fake websites using their details. Licensed moneylenders are also not allowed to approve loans remotely. Please contact licensed moneylenders via the contact details and visiting only the websites found in this list https://rom.mlaw.gov.sg/files/ML%20Lists/ML%20List%20as%20at%2001March2021.pdf.

column1: i meet this girl thru Facebook dating

I made some earnings and was able to cash out. Next few days she ask me to put more money inside as there was a event ongoing to get bonus

column4: I transferred and got the bonus event and i noticed i couldn't withdraw my money and the criteria to withdraw is to top up another $30K. This was when I realised that I was being scammed. the girl even offer to help me and encourage me to borrow. i even ask her as she claimed her money was stuck also but from the way she sound is like is not even concern about that money. I stopped contacting her as I noticed she's a scammer. When i came to this website and read more about it. that when i realize i was 1 of the victims that had fall to prey. luckily

column1: i am a malaysian living in singapore
column2: female 38 years old. Yesterday morning (13 August 2021) I received a phone call made from Singapore local number to my Singapore SIM card stated that it is from Singapore Ministry of Health (MOH). He told me that my passport has been registered in Shanghai
column3: China mobile and has been identified spreading a fake Covid-19 text messages and its an heavy offence. He then offered to transferred my call to 'Shanghai Interpol Office' to lodge my police report. The man who answered the call then asked for my Whatsapp phone number (which is registered under my Malaysia simcard) he texted me his Police Employee Card with picture identify himself as 'Officer Zhang
column4: He then asked me to send him through WhatsApp my passport front picture as he needed to carry on the investigation. I was panic at that moment and did not recognized it was a scam and sent him my passport copy front page showing my signature. He then told me to hold the line and when he came back he said he has also identify my passport number has a China Bank account that associated with money laundering. I was again in shock. He kept asking me questions like where I might use my passport before or have I lost it. And he asked if I have any bank account in Singapore? I told him no
column5: and only have bank accounts in Malaysia. He asked for the names which I provided. But I did not disclose the bank details such as numbers or ATM cards. He then told me I need to cooperate with him so he can assist me. He informed me that he will contact me back 3 hours later as he will have a 'meeting' with his superior on how to have this issue handle. it was 12:30 noon when we hang up. He told me not to share this information about the call with anyone even my family. As soon as he hang up
column6: I immediately contacted MOH hotline and they told me it is definitely fraud as they did not make such call. a police report has been made immediately and i am trying to contact the Malaysian Embassy in Singapore as well because my identity has been compromised.

column1: I had received a call in the morning on 13 August 2021 from my house phone. a recorded message in Chinese stating there is a quarantine order
column2: instructing to press 9 to continue. I did not do so and let the call continue till it ended by itself. I only managed to record a bit of the message.

column1: Received a call that is a voice recording telling me I need to contact MOH urgently and it's related to COVID-19. I should press a button to talk to MOH.

I was searching for room rental and had posted my info in this website(https://rentinsingapo??.com.sg/).I received many legitimate offers but one of them was an obvious scam. He introduced himself as Ahmed. He claimed to have moved abroad due to work circumstance and is trying to find someone to take over his apartment. He gave me an HDB block address but the photos of the unit have condo furnishing and has a bathtub which is rare in HDB units.The rental fee is also too good to be true for a master's bedroom. There were too many red flags. But what really gave it away is when he asked me to buy itunes card. If someone ask you to buy itunes card
column2: never trust them! I hope that this information will help you spot the danger before it's too late.

column1: Claim to be MOH with multiple important not treated documents in English and Chinese. Ask press 3 . It was clearly a scam call.

Someone called claiming to be from Starhub. saying that there is a high activity from my internet overseas for the past few days. and i am at risk of a cybercrime attack. He asked me to download a software on my laptop called ultraviewer and taught me the steps to see the activity via cmd. was told to key in netstat in cmd to see the internet activities from other countries. He then told me that he would my call to the cybercrime officer to help me with it. I was told to provide my name
column2: dob
column3: address
column4: email and contact number. which i did. I only came to realise that it was a scam when he asked me to log in to DBS online via my laptop.. i told him i am not comfortable in doing it since I am open to cybercrime now. he kept pushing me by telling me to log in so that he could teach me how to transact safely. I refused and told him to give me his contact number so that I could back to verify. but he refused and asked me to follow his instructions so i went online to search for cybercrime scam via my computer laptop and refused to login to dbs as per his request. i I told him I would call the police myself to solve this problem and hang up the phone. but i have no idea if he has access any information from my laptop or not. after i hang down the phone
column5: I restarted my laptop and uninstall the app that they asked me to download. i also called up Starhub to check on my internet activities and they told me it is fine. no unusual activities. I also went to make a police report.

He then made me go to a website on google to search for ‚Äú‰∏äÊµ∑Êµ¶‰∏úÂàÜÂ±Ä‚Äù(shanghai Pudong branch) and click on their ‚Äòofficial‚Äô website to check for the international contact number below the website. column1: Scammer pretends to be from singtel alert! number +659753101 Caller claimed that my wifi received complaints and reason of my wifi issue is that there are 25 other people tapping onto my wifi and use. For him to check and retify the problem
column2: i have to follow his instruction. I asked for verification to determine he is from singtel
column3: he first sigh and then replied softly gibberish enough for me to already suspect. 1st sign was that he instructed me to search for 'terminal' in mac . at this moment another hint to suspect his next step is indeed for me to type a certain codes which then enable him to control my computer and possibility of hacking further. of course i did not bother to type anything he instructed in my terminal. when he asked have you typed in those.. i said no not yet
column4: i am still trying to verify and check if you are from singtel. Immediately he gave off a 2nd sigh and hang up. I have called Singtel to verify if there is any call record on their end of such engagement
column5: zero call from Singtel. Moreover
column6: singtel does not call you if you have internet issues. it is the owner of the problem whom will be calling Singtel. - take note! column7: seeing the comment gave in singtel fb page. Hope that my story will help alert fellow citizens of this scam!

column1: Internet Love Scam; INVESTMENT SCAM The standard MO is get your whatsapp number
column2: then start chatting with you
column3: and very quickly "falling in love" with you. multiple countries This story was parents divorced
column4: only child with a very strong single mother. seemingly very close to mum. all these are just there to make you let your guard down thinking they have good moral values. same for other sweet talk. This was a business whatsapp number. initially looked genuine with +65 i.e. sg but why a business account. scammer also moved quickly off the coffee meet bagel site to whatsapp claiming to use the CMB app rarely. usually flawless success story are too good to be true. if you analyse clearly
column5: you will notice loopholes in the conversations when you ask more questions. scammers will usually try to avoid questions so that you will detect less inconsistencies in the dialogue. scammer requested to invest in cryptocurrency together to reap the lucrative profits. i count myself lucky that I was not exposed to sophiscated websites and apps with fake statistics as i read other stories with such websites. fyi might work in groups - some might be smarter than others. i m amazed at how well educated and opiniated these syndicates are. no money was lost.

column1: Received a robocall from "MOH" threatening me with quarantine. I knew it was scam and hung up. We have included a link to a recording that a member of the public submitted to us. https://youtu.be/vhAiSGDYHa0
I met the guy in facebook dating last 21-may. He introduced himself as philip chang
column2: a 41 year old singaporean who grew up in houston texas. He‚Äôs an oil rig engineer and independent contractor with plans to settle down in singapore hence he‚Äôs looking for a partner. The persona he has created is someone who‚Äôs an introvert with little knowledge of the internet. Growing up as an asian in the us has turned him into a quiet loner due to the bullying. His dad died when he was a kid and grew up with his mom until she died of cancer 8 years ago. He has an uncle
column3: a retired priest currently staying in a home. He only had 2 girlfriends in the past
column4: 1st turned out to be a drug addict and the 2nd cheated on him with someone he knows. Since then he is married to his job.He was very patient
column5: we chatted for almost 2 months in getting to know each other. Part of his daily routine is to do sermons
column6: studying the bible by himself. He went to orphanages with his mom to donate. He shared a story of his worker stealing money from him through online banking which is why he doesn‚Äôt use online banking anymore. One day
column7: he won a bidding contract in ukraine and had to fly there with his workers. His agent was waiting there with local workers. In ukraine
column8: he shared the strict rules in safety measures in the rig like they can‚Äôt take pictures
column9: videos or calls. He began sending love poems via email. Suddenly there were sea pirates who attacked their rig but no one was hurt. Our daily routine was chatting to find out if the other is ok. He‚Äôs able to fill my days with his messages. Then came my fear
column10: their operation is now on-hold since their drilling machine has broken down beyond fixing. He has already used most of his funds in fixing it before. He has a deadline to meet and the only option is to buy a new machine worth us$ 178k. If he can‚Äôt finish the project
column11: he‚Äôll be sued for breach of contract. He asked if i could loan him money. I was in denial
column12: that i should give people the benefit of the doubt. So i agreed to transfer sgd3000
column13: an amount that i am prepared to lose. I told him that it‚Äôs the best i could offer to show my sincerity. So he asked me to transfer to his agent‚Äôs account in bangkok bank. He contacted me again saying he just needed a few more to buy the machine but this time i declined. I only found out about the scam and reported it right away.There are really heartless people who won‚Äôt feel any remorse in hurting people for their personal gain.

column1: Day 1: Received a call from this number

column1: Email claimed to from singpost requesting for a couple of dollars payment for the delivery of items. Asked for details of credit card. Suspected that it is scam because when you clicked on the detail of f email address

column4: block the sender's email address.

column1: I was searching for money lender online to find one that was at lower interest and can be able to give a longer loan tenor he name himself as James from oasis 1 credit pte ltd and when you google search you will find oasis credit at Clementi. He followed up with me for a month and the website looks legit and I even received a auto-generated email from the ministry of law hence i thought it will be like a debt consolidation plan whereby you have to pay to the ministry of law hence i transfer $2500 over and afterwards he got another person to call me and said you have to pay another $2500 to open this uob account in which i did transfer and i know the next day i called both the numbers using normal line was unable to call through i was scammed. I have made a police report and close my bank account. I might not be able to recover my losses. Editor's Note: Please note that unlicensed moneylenders can impersonate as licensed moneylenders by creating fake websites using their details. Licensed moneylenders are not allowed to put up advertisements online (including social media)
column2: SMS or messaging apps. Please contact licensed moneylenders via the contact details and visiting only the websites found in this list: https://rom.mlaw.gov.sg/files/ML%20Lists/ML%20List%20as%20at%2001March2021.pdf. Licensed moneylenders are not allowed to approve loans remotely.

column1: matched with this guy in cmb dating app. there are so many red flags
column2: writing this to create awareness. 1. he's not in sg
column3: he's in shanghai. 1st red flag
column4: as someone keen on dating should be in same location as you
column5: in order to meet up. his reason was he always comes to sg for business & thinking of settling down & get a pr. he will visit sg in sep. 2. he asked for whatsapp
column6: the number used to whatsapp is malaysia country code +60 he said this number he used when he went for business trip to malaysia
column7: i asked him when was his last visit to malaysia
column8: he said 2 yrs ago. WHILE I READ ONLINE WHATSAPP IS BANNED IN CHINA UNLESS YOU USE VPN. so i asked if he used vpn
column9: his answer was no i used mobile data
column10: when my data finished i will use vpn. i really want to laugh
column11: this guy did not understand what he was saying. this whole conversation with him is another red flag. 3. he shared about trading gold using metatrader 4 (mt4). asked me to download & open demo account. i'm actually a trader myself & used mt4 for forex trading
column12: but i pretend & play along with him. the broker he's using is glluck
column13: you can find the name in mt4 & website of the company (based in us)
column14: everything looks legit. only that when i googled for review of glluck
column15: there was a post saying this company not regulated & warn to stay away. he said he has "teacher" who know very well the timing to trade
column16: once the teacher tells him when to trade he will share with me so we can trade at same time. he texted me to trade that night
column17: but i didn't reply his message
column18: so he was trying to call me twice
column19: i didn't answer. after that he showed me screen shot of his trading profit 35
column20: 100 usd. to trade with this profit
column21: you need to have a least usd100k capital. if he could make this much in one night
column22: he won't be sharing with a stranger whom he never met. after that night i didn't continue to chat with him because i knew from the beginning this guy is a scam. i just wanted to know what's the scam tactic since this type of scam was not heard before in sg. i did a google search
column23: it's very common in china and hkg
column24: they use mt4 so it looks legit
column25: they will then manipulate the broker system (or create fake broker)
column26: they will make you create live account after trying demo account
column27: let you earn money from trading
column28: but later the more you put in
column29: you won't be able to get the money back.

I was trying to find a loan of $10
column2: 000 and therefore
column3: i would search on the internet to look out for some licensed money lenders. On 1 night
column4: i decided to find a website and fill up my particulars such as my name
column5: phone number and email address as i thought that the loan website was rather interesting in giving out its interest rates. On the following day
column6: i was contacted by a whatsapp number and this number represents its company
column7: "lending bee pte ltd". I chatted with this number and they sound like they are a legitimate business. Eventually we came to an agreement that i have to pay an upfront of $2
column8: 000 for admin & stamp charges which i've paid too before the approval of my loan as the loan officer said that my $2
column9: 000 would be refundable at the end of my loan. However
column10: after paying of the $2
column12: they demanded another $1
column13: 300 to activate my case and to access their banking accounts. I found it suspicious as there is a hidden fee which I did not sign in the imposter contract. I therefore knew that it was a scam and decided to call my bank to tell them about the problems that I've faced and made a police report immediately. I now knew that singapore licensed money lenders are not allowed to advertise their services online and that it will always be safer to acquire a loan at their actual office instead of doing it online. I did not know that this was a scam as this is my 1st time trying to acquire a loan.Editor's Note: Please note that unlicensed moneylenders can impersonate as licensed moneylenders by creating fake websites using their details. Licensed moneylenders are also not allowed to approve loans remotely. Please contact licensed moneylenders via the contact details and visiting only the websites found in this list https://rom.mlaw.gov.sg/files/ML%20Lists/ML%20List%20as%20at%2001March2021.pdf.

column1: Was contaCted by ray via whatsapp regarding a loan offer. As i was in urgent need of money i started to enquire more and sent my Payslip

After 1 week i kepT asking for the account number for repaYment but ray Told me to pay $150 first for deferment even though i did not ask for any deferment to the test loan. A few days later
column3: he gave me another account number and told me that the repayment amount was $650 even though i had already paid $150 before. He mentioned that the initial $150 would be ‚Äúrefunded‚Äù to me along with the $3000 loan. That‚Äôs when i figured that i had been scammed. Not wanting to deal with any harassment
column4: I transferred the $650 to that account number and told ray to cancel my initial loan application. I then made a police report. I had To wait almost 2 years for my bank account to be unfrozen by the bank due to the long Investigation process. So much inconvenience all to (but) no thanks to the scammer!

column1: I would like to share scams that are happening on social media and dating platforms. I would like to share certain details which might be good knowledge for the public on what to look out for and the telltale signs. This is a potential Love and Cryptocurrency Scam situation. First telltale sign: Display pictures of matches are usually very attractive females/males. However
column2: such pictures are often reused. So there are two things which are easy to spot. 1) Pictures are usually low quality and low in resolution and grainy looking. 2) There is a function in Google which you can do "Google image search". https://images.google.com/ Users can screenshot the profile picture and upload using the link to do an image search. Should the image be reused a couple of times
column3: it will show up in the search with multiple results. (An almost immediate sign that the account is a scam account) Second telltale sign : She had a phone number which was a nonlocal number (+852) 1) While this may not be a straightforward sign.. this should raise some alarm. Third telltale sign : Weird looking URL: Below is the URL sent by Aditi : https://d.app66372.xyz/?id=782ce5254eba50d0fc21c498c0975b8c 1) URL ends with xyz which are usually nonlegitimate platforms for trading. Official trading platforms should also come with .com or .sg 2) Should one open the link
column4: images are seen to be in low resolution and low quality. 3) The text on the website is often reused. After doing a simple google with the first text in the URL "140‰∏áÂçï/ÁßíÁöÑÊ†∏ÂøÉÊíÆÂêàÊäÄÊúØÈ¶ñÂÆ∂Âª∫Á´ãÊäïËµÑËÄÖ‰øùÊä§Âü∫Èáë-SAFUÂü∫Èáë" Google images immediately return multiple instances of the same text. Below are two links that google returned
column5: which had a direct replica of the link Aditi gave. https://d.wbgtd.buzz/?id=d24609dfd72fa52a70d05b2bbc1e7b85 https://d.wbgtd.buzz/index_zh-TW?id=d24609dfd72fa52a70d05b2bbc1e7b85 Of course
column6: by this time - I return the two links above Aditi blocked me instantly. Forth telltale sign : Aditi was extremely persuasive in trying to get me to "earn as much as her"
column7: getting her uncle and sister to "teach me". The full phone number in the case is +852 9084 8107 Also note: Aditi was able to say where she lived in Singapore. In this case
column8: she said Serangoon and named "Forest Woods" as her place of residence.

column3: and looked very much like the bank. Except that it had signed off with a personal phone number and its contents are regarding loans. I referred to my previous SMS OTPs coming from the actual bank
column4: are realized the real Bank sender is under the name "DBS Bank". (captial "B"
column5: with Small caps for "ank")

column1: Beware of the credit-for-sex scams using gift cards as a form of payment for sex. What they will do is ask you to purchase an itunes gift card at a nearby convience store before meeting
column2: after purchase the potential scammer wanted me to reveal the itunes gift card redemption code before meeting me. Decline that offer and move to another person from a trusted source (keep the gift card to yourself if you have purchased). Lessons to be learned: do not use gift cards as a payment for sex services
column3: only accept cash on hand or meet up first before you make any online transactions between both parties. I hope my experience brings up some alert to the community
column4: do stay safe everyone...

column1: I Was trying out the Facebook dating feature and spoke to two different Chinese man. First red flag was they promptly asked to move to other apps for communication. Please take note as they are using this period whereby people can't meet to gain trust and manipulate you. they suddenly call me sweetheart out of nowhere and acted like they care about my daily life. Sometimes they will voice call and send pictures while demanding yours (Never give your Photos). Two different tricks used WERE: 1. Ask you to help with downloading an app to play a GAME because their sibling can't use it 2. Ask you to download an app to make a quick income. Very easy in 20 Mins. For the first one
column2: you see the immediate rewards and will feel tempted to do it yourself. You just need to create an account with your email. To transfer money
column3: you need to upload your ID. I did it and regretted because of possible identity theft. They Will need you to transfer money to an Account belonging to someone. Which is very suspicious. For the second one
column4: the moment I refused to credit money into the Account
column5: that person immediately blew up and acted like I was in the wrong. The explanation for the app was a money investment game. But it was in fact a fraudulent get rich quick scam
column6: hoping that you throw in a big sum of money into a suspicious account. They are preying on vulnerable women and they are very good at making it sound like they care about you. Beware ladies. These man are professionals.

column20: 000 in order to be able to withdraw my money. Feeling desperate

column22: 000 target

column1: THere is a whatsapp message about earning money by part time The term that they like to use is affiliate marketing. they claim to THEY CLAIM TO WORK UNDER LAZADA THIRD PARTIES. 1) order the goods in lazada
column2: snap shot to them 2) wire money to a local dbs bank account and they will refund you with the commission 3) submit the snap shot and complete the task 4) they claim to complete 3 tasks to earn $38
column3: 5/6 tasks for $ 68 and blah blah blah it will be 1 local line to contact you for the bank acc number
column4: phone number and full name to so called register you in. the profile is a chinese with suit on
column5: look profressional like those real estate agent with good english. he will guide us thru the intro. so they will create a chat group "exchange group" with the lazada logo
column6: however if you take note
column7: there is quite a few group they have. at first
column8: i will doubt the job then you will see the members inside the group would start to start a conversation within the group and showcase the job completed. I was doubltful then i just quit. next day
column9: they will ask if you want to join back
column10: most likely is another group. that is how i know there are numerous group. here the funny part
column11: if you see carefully
column12: almost 90% of the members will be the same number and profile picture. and in the different group

column14: "what do you mean by claim rewards? "
column15: "ok
column16: i will give it a try if i have time" etc etc. when you realise they are completing task on the previous group. another giveaway will be the numbers inside the whatsapp group
column17: when you speak to them
column18: they will not reply you with using voice voice and their answer is pretty standard. the best part is their english is so frequent english that there is no any singlish
column19: spelling mistake or broken english which was common in our region.

column1: A lady with a strong Indian ascent claimed that she is a Singtel technician. she called and ask about the no of lights blinking on the router. then she will say that they notice that there is high data usage of up to 70% which is abnormal. she will then ask you how many devices are using the router. Then she would scare you by saying that they notice 20 over devices connected and that's where I told her that its impossible as my wireless network is password protect. she keep trying to dig further which I told her off to drop me a email and I say i'm not going to explain anymore on the phone where she just hang up during the argument. by the way
column2: the SingTel internet account was signed up by my wife and my account was mobile only. so there is no way that they will call me on internet issues.

column1: Got to know 2 potential scammers via okc/cmb: 1) Lin yang (via okc around mar 2021) - first big red flag was asking to converse in chinese. then he said he was in sg for his business and his uncle taught him how to do some investment and he wanted to teach me how. i said i wasnt interested as i was doing my own investments but he insisted and said that just 1k would be enough to try sth new. he also sent over flowers and cake despite us not having met before. the 2nd time he tried to persuade me to join but i didnt want to and then he ghosted me after that. 2) shiweize (via cmb May 2021) - did not talk to him much as it was a big red flag when he asked to converse in chinese as he grew up in china though he is a local. i said no i cant do chinese and so he continued to talk in english but when i asked him more specific questions about his ns
column2: he couldnt answer and didnt reply after that.

column1: Almost lost money to a scammer. This girl added me in line asking which part of sg i am in
column2: i replied in Yishun . She then said she is also from yishun and then proceeded to offer me her sex services. She told me to meet up at Yishun
column3: once there she told me take picture of the surroundings. I took it and sent to her. Then she said she is on the way and asked me for my hp no which i gave
column4: then she said a guy will call me and i just needed to say i am not police can already. The guy called me
column5: this was when my phone app highlighted in red with indonesia no +62000000001 with over 500 reports of scam
column6: i picked up the call knowingly it is likely to end in scam. The guy i didn't catch the name
column7: asked me if i am the first time using the service
column8: i said yes. Then he told me because its 1st time
column9: i will need to go axs machine to purchase not sure what credit
column10: when the purchase is made and receipt printed
column11: i will pass it to the girl upon meeting up . At this point i hesitated and but still joined the queue at the axs machine. I backed out and told the guy machine is spoilt. Then he asked me to go 7 eleven to buy a google play store gift card
column12: which i refused cause i know at this point
column13: it is definitely a scam. His tone started to have the threatening effect. He stressed that the sexual services are backed by gang call 369. And he also said he has my hp no which he is able to check my particulars. And that now even if i do not want service i still need to buy the gift card and pass it to the girl. I refused and continue making my way home. Blocked all nos and deleted line account. Nothing was lost except my hp no.

column1: The caller was trying to impersonate an official from high court of singapore. He was speaking in heavily accented Mandarin and vehemently defending that he was from the chinese department of the high court. as an ex-civil servant
column2: i knew straight off it was a scam call and questioned him on his identity
column3: making him more irritable before calling him a scammer and cutting the line.

column1: This kind of scams are quite new to me
column2: and mostly to many others too. recently i shared my address info to a carousell seller so she could send out the items i ordered to me. today though
column3: i received a message from someone named championcou. the message went like this. Your parcel IMS00925X18 has been scheduled for delivery to xx xx DR #xx-x Sxxxxxx by 2021-06-01. ~Champion Courier *inserts link* they ended off the text stating that the message was from champion courier. confused as i dont remember getting anything mailed by champion courier
column4: i asked my seller about it. she said that she sent out my item by singpost. i trust her becuase ive done multiple transactions to and from with her and so far there werent any issues. thinking the message could be a scam
column5: i searched about these type of scams and what they do to you but i ended up with only a few articles on it. they claim that these scams will insert viruses into your mobile devices once you click on the tracking link. however
column6: that didnt scare me that much. what scares me the most is that people had access to my address and my contact number. furthermore
column7: i had just moved here recently. i only remember revealing my address on whatsapp and that's about it. i am quite sure that there are some hackers out there that are able to get information from your text messages. so
column8: do be careful when revealing your personal information online. even though i have not lost any money (yet) i still feel that the public needs to know about it as these scams may lead to many other unfavourable circumstances to vulnerable people Note: how i confirmed the message was fake was that i went to the offical champion courier website and searched for 'my' parcel with the tracking number provided to me but the website was unable to find an actual parcel registered under that number. also
column9: i watched the tracking from the link provided. it showed me that the courier driver circled round the neighbourhood near me but it never stopped at my estate.

column1: 1. received a call on 24 May 2021
column2: at 1:55PM from this number and it was a recorded message stating that i did not respond or reply to dbs despite repeated attempts. I was then asked to press '3' to continue the call. I hung up as it did not make sense reaching out to me on my office mobile number as i had not provided this to dbs. so
column3: this is definitely a phishing scam as the action to press '3' is to ascertain that they are reaching out to a human and hence any response would mean being 'baited' by them. nothing was lost except for time but thought it should be made aware to the public if they receive similar calls.

column1: Received a spoof call from "Singtel". The person on the other line said they were from Singtel tech support an there were problems with internet access in the network. They wanted to speak with whoever paid the bill and tried to verify information with me. I hung up at this point. providing the number above as they appear to be using a singapore phone number.
Received call from 6429358? with no sound at first. This already triggered my alert since most scams call start with first 5-10 seconds of silence
column2: maybe due to overseas connection. Anyway
column3: After about 6 seconds
column4: a male voice with South Asian accent said he was calling from singtel technical support and that the purpose of the call was to check on my Internet connection. This confirmed it was an impersonator since I am not a singtel customer. But I continued to play along to waste their time and money on the call and to see what else they would say. The modus operandi was similar to other stories shared - unauthorised usage of my Internet at night by 20-25 devices hacking the network. By which time
column5: I was really not keen to listen anymore so I said I am not a singtel customer and I am recording this call. The caller hung up immediately. No financial loss
column6: just time and some brain cells.

column3: and i have to transfer him back the extra 10k he sent by mistake. He apologised and offered a good deal for the extra 10k. He then sent me an email from mas requiring me to pay 3k refundable validation fee to receive 20k + 3k. So i paid after that

Editor's Note: Please note that unlicensed moneylenders can impersonate as licensed moneylenders by creating fake websites using their details. Licensed moneylenders are not allowed to put up advertisements online (including social media)
column7: SMS or messaging apps. Please contact licensed moneylenders via the contact details and visiting only the websites found in this list: https://rom.mlaw.gov.sg/files/ML%20Lists/ML%20List%20as%20at%2001March2021.pdf Licensed moneylenders are not allowed to approve loans remotely.

column1: This happened to my best friend. She does not want to report to the police as she did not lose any money and she feels embarrassed that she fell for a scam.She was on a dating app and chatted with this mature looking chinese man who claimed to be a successful entrepreneur looking to expand his agro tech and cryptocurrency projects to Singapore. He is currently based in the Sates.She fell in love with him after some months of chatting online and over the phone. I did warn her that it sounds like a scam because why would a successful us-based businessman be on a dating app to look for love? But she told me he is real and that she is aware of scams so she will be careful.One day he asked her to be a co-investor together with him in his new Singapore-based business and also told her that he wants to come to Singapore to find her. She was about to transfer $5k to his us-based agent to handle the company registration but as she was quite broke at the time
column2: she asked if she could wait until next salary month. Then that guy kept rushing her
column3: that was when she felt something was wrong. She asked him more questions about his company and finally he ghosted her.At first she felt depressed and wondered if it was her fault. Only after our friends met up to cheer her up
column4: she then told us this story and we helped her realised it was really a scam.

column1: Please do not engage These LOAN financial experts from FB. They are using real companies DETAILS

column3: license and address. Don't trust when they say fuss free applications. I have been scammed of $2200. Lesson learned the hard way. On 5 may 2021
column4: I chanced upon this GS credit Singapore on FB. I was looking for a loan of $5000 with repayment terms of 12mths. I did a check AND the LICENSE no. and office address is legitimate
column5: included in THE moneylenders LIST. My MISTAKE WAS not CALLING the real phone number instead of the person HENRY. I asked why cannot go office
column6: Henry said due to CURRENT pandemic SITUATION
column7: meet up was stopped They will ASK for your ic
column8: BANK statements and next of kin's contacts. Do not give anything to them. In short
column9: AFTER their 'VALIDATION process'
column10: THEY WILL then ask you to send $500 deposit to them but They will DEPOSIT $250 to your bank account. After that they make you wait for some time
column11: contract states you have to pay $750 as insurance for them if you default on your payments. Its when they send you a TAX invoice by Credit Bureau Singapore which told me that i was scammed. They ASK me to clear the 'govt Tax" in order to transfer the LOAN to be completed. I told them I will CHECK CBS for the validity and THEY panicked. I will pay them the extra if really I was taxed on the Next day. The 'finance" guy said ok and said I will get the LOAN the next day. I immediately made a police REPORT and informed CBS and blocked And report them from whatsapp. There's definitely a few of them. Editor's Note: Please note that unlicensed moneylenders can impersonate as licensed moneylenders by creating fake websites using their details. Licensed moneylenders are not allowed to put up advertisements online (including social media)

column1: We met on an online dating app. He took time to convinced me that he was a real deal by having a regular work schedule time to talk only during the so called free time and sending photos of his daily activities once in a while. His excuse for not being in Singapore was he needed to visit his parents back in China and needed some time before coming back to Singapore. He started sharing how he has a side income through cryptocurrency usdt trading. Despite my initial reluctance
column2: he insisted that I should try. The initial amount started at only usd$800 but over time he would pretend to put in money to my-so called account and pretend to trade on the app with me to earn money. There was emotional pressure and time pressure put on me to put in the investments as he claimed he went to borrow money just to enable my account to trade in the highest category section. The worst was he actually had a fake relative who joins the chat to pretend that he was a real deal too. Eventually their fake advice ended up making me lose all my so called investments. Which is probably all fake transactions on a trading platform. The biggest fear now is my data floating out there since real data of photo ID had to be submitted for creating an account. Do not trust any Chinese successful professional online whom you do not see in real life and don't invest unless it is an accredited Mas investment products. I was emotionally affected by the experience and lost my common sense to judge rationally.

So I asked her who was that. then the scammer asked her to go to a quiet room so that he can record some details clearly. i intervened at this moment and asked her to hang up the phone immediately. when the scammer heard my voice
column5: he himself hang up the call. Please don't fall into such traps. starthub or other company will not call and cancel any service within such short notice and they will never inform you such matter over phone. although she talked to them quite sometime
column6: no confidential information had been shared with scammer other than phone number. hopefully everything will be fine

column1: Caller with a thick indian accent claimed to be calling from singtel . mentioning that there is a surge in my internet usage. asked me to hold on the line to speak to his senior technician named sam thomas who asked me to go infront of my laptop to key in some details. When i asked for verification of my address and name he did not have it and started shouting at me saying that i dont understand how serious this is. He hung up once I told him I knew it was a scam.
I got a call with an Indian guy around 9:20am
column2: the call volume was really soft at the start and when i got him to turn the volume up
column3: he kept cutting out. When i could finally hear him
column4: I asked him to identified himself. He ignored it as though he didn't hear me before proceeding to ask if i was the one paying the internet bills which i did answer yes. He then said that abnormal usage was detected on my wifi throughout the night (something along the lines of 25 users using my wifi during the night) and asked if i shared my wifi password with anyone. I then asked him to identify himself and he finally answered that he is from singtel. Since I had no internet lines with singtel
column5: it was obviously a fake so i put down the call straight away. Do note that he not once tried to even confirm my identity and address which a real telco would have done 1st before even sharing any info from their end. Also
column6: real telco knows who their calling and will not make unsolicited phone calls informing you that there are problems with your internet connection!

column1: A guy with strong Indian accent called saying they received feedback of slow and lagging internet connection. Later
column2: he claimed that my connection was used by others from overseas to carry out illegal activities under my name. This is such a common scam. Beware!

column1: I received a scam call
column2: saying I'm using my phone number to spread misinformation about COVID-19. I ask where the caller is calling from. The caller replied that he is calling from Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) Singapore. I asked if he can show any evidence. He said he could not provide anything. He just want to tell me that my phone number will be suspended in two hours. This scam call is from a real person. he can answer your any questions and give you real warning. I have also search this incidence on the internet. There are many people who received such phone calls. Beware!

column1: Received a phone call from hp+65 9716 211? As i felt it is a scam I hung up on him and he never call back. otherwise i will risk that my company's server or computer being hacked.

column2: i didnt make any calls to singtel

column1: I usually receive robocalls but this morning I spoke to a person who claimed to be from call from a Chinese lady claiming she's from DB. She shared that she has a document for me and requested that I go visit someplace to collect it. I am concerned as she VERIFIED my full name WHEN I ANSWERED THE CALL.

I am shijo and work in cyber security industry. This report is just to help others and maybe the authorities to better educate the public at large or track down the syndicate. i picked up the call and started the conversation fully aware that it was a scam call. myintention was to understand scammers real motive so that i can probably alert others who may be less computer savy. I recorded the whole coversation too. this is how the call progressed... 1.i received a call from this scammer (i could hear other agents too. so this is a big team) 2.i was told that the call is from singtel tech support 3.the caller claims that my internet was being used by ohers illegaly 3.the caller asked me to go through a series of steps on my computer to convince me that many external forces are connected to my computer. they wanted me to run 'netstat' commands 4.i pretended that i was following their insructions when i was not 5.as i work in cyber security
column2: i am very well aware of those commands and the expected output. so i played along to understand their real intention without running any single command --------- so here it is: ultimately the scammer wants you to access a remote control website and download their remote control executable so that they will be able to login remotely and take over your computer. website name: ultraviewer.net (i never accessed this site as i didnt want any drive by download or pugings to be installed on my comuter) i just wanted to share the scammers mode of operandi and hope this helps others. thanks

column1: I share this story to make all the females out there to be more aware that love scammer needs to be taken seriously. This love scammer is so professionally manipulative. Scammer bio: match on tinder

column4: has thick French accent 34yo

column7: i summarize his characteristics: 1. In the beginning

column9: asked to move to chat platform in my case is Whatsapp. 2. After a few days

column11: and keep saying will meet you in person soon and will buy you a flight ticket to visit him. 4. He is willing to invest his energy and time in you and being so patience until he wins your trust and heart. Don‚Äôt be surprised if he is willing to do this for a long time
column12: my case was 1 month
column13: some were more than 6 months. 5. He said want to settle down and buy a house in Singapore and asked me to find out how much the house price (wow‚Ä¶so convincing right?) 6. Once he knew you fall for him and gain your trust. He will suddenly tell you that something bad happened to him. After 3 weeks of chatting
column14: he told me he will travel overseas to win a contract and showed his picture on a flight. He told me he needs to pay for the unexpected contract registration for about usd15
column15: 000 and he was out of cash. He said he cannot use his france card because it is not activated for overseas use and needs 4 working days
column16: so he was asking me shyly to lend him usd2000 to survive for 4 days. He asked to transfer to his driver‚Äôs bank account or his bitcoin. At first
column17: i rejected and he said it‚Äôs alright
column18: it‚Äôs not your fault and comforted me which is his technique to make you feel guilty and worried about him even more as it is real. He even said i still love you no matter what
column19: saying good night as usual. The next day
column20: i felt bad as ‚Äúhis woman‚Äù so i almost transferred to his bitcoin but thank god i went through this website before going to the atm.Overall
column21: there are obvious signs from love scammer: 1. He will never do a video call with you even after you ask several times. 2. He will never show you any of his social media (even he does then you need to check with google image or bing) 3. He will never meet you in person even he has been texting and calling you regardless how long. 4. In any circumstances
column22: do not ever transfer any money/ invest to a person you have never met in person period!

column4: please be wary as it could be a scam call. Since April 2020
column5: the ‚Äò+‚Äô sign prefix will be displayed on phone screens for all international incoming calls. Domestic calls will not display the ‚Äò+‚Äô sign prefix. This measure will help consumers who are not expecting any overseas calls to be more vigilant and exercise greater care when answering calls showing a ‚Äò+‚Äô prefix. If you are not expecting any overseas calls
column6: please do not call back.

column1: Person called me using the number 68920830 with a strong Indian accent. Claimed to be from the technical dept of singtel. Claimed to be calling regarding my internet connection (but i do not have a singtel internet account at all). I asked her who is looking for (i. E. Name
column2: house address etc). But she could not provide it. Claimed that as it is a call recorded for training purposes
column3: she could not say the details in the call. Just kept saying that she is looking for the "house owner of this internet connection"
column4: which sounds extremely fishy. She said she wanted nothing but my time. I didn‚Äôt bother and hung up. Editor's note: Please note that scammers will use spoofing technology to create fake numbers to cover their tracks. Numbers shown on users' Caller IDs are often invalid numbers or belonging to people who did not make the calls. The most effective measure against such phone impersonation scams is to be able to identify the scam and hang up.

column1: A call from a lady (sounded like Indian) who identify as Singtel internet service provider. Later
column2: she passed the call to her so called technician to get more information. This guy called micheal (sounds like Filipino) said a lot of hackers around 20+ hackers have been actively hacked into my system. He would try to guide me by using my computer to identify the hackers. He asked me to typed "cmd" run the files. And ask me to read out the details to him. I paused and asked can i call Singtel to verify this call. He started to get panic and told me he was a third party that Singtel engaged and no records. When I insisted and he hung up the phone. I would like to share this incident as I hope no one will fall in their prey. Thanks for reading.

column1: I received a message saying my Internet was hacked and being used by 3rd Parties. I did not respond and ignored it. Today i received a follow-up call from "STEVe ROgers" (indian Accent) saying he would help resolve the issue. i played along long enough to see what he wanted to do - which was downloaded a "TEAMVIEW" app so he could remote fix the "ISSUE". I then refused and asked for his singtel number and ID - he gave Id number of 456139 which I am sure is fake but no phone number. I hung up and called singtel - who confirmed that it was not them and therefore a scam.Editor's Note: We would advise that members of the public do not entertain scam calls but end the calls immediately. Try not to pick up calls with the "+" or "+ 65" prefix as these are signs that the calls have originated from overseas.

I got tempted by a online ad on locanto with the girl offering services for 200 for 3 hours. i then Proceeded to find the girl on line and made an appointment with her. she made sure to check on line which part of singapore im staying before giving me the address to meet her. During the meet up she will first give excuses such as being late and then ask for your phone number. she will then inform you that someone else would be calling you for security purposes. next a guy called himself (chinese speaking) ah bao called saying he is from some company and then he will ask you to go to the store that's conveniently nearby and buy stored-value cards. luckily in my case the cards happened to be out of stock and hence i paid an lesser amount for the cards. next they will give more excuses to convince you to buy the cards even if it means paying more and saying that they will pay you back the extra amount later. in my case i refused since I felt something was wrong after i bought the cards. However
column2: my lustful self decided that i can afford to lose 160 to either have a chance to have sex or to buy a lesson. so once i refused
column3: the scammers used the line account to persuade me to download and install an app on my phone and sign up as an member saying that will give me the discount to make up for the missing 40. after i scanned the .apk file with an anti-virus app which shows that it was fine
column4: i then installed the app. but that's when they started asking for more money saying its to ensure you are not with the police. it was then i realised i was definitely being scammed and decided to pull out from it. unfortunately the app that i installed earlier came back to bite me and i realised that they could track my location using that app and it also downloaded numbers of my contacts. the ah bao person then called again and started the threats about your family and how he will divulge what you did to your friends and family. what i did from here was to ignore the threats and brace myself in case anything he said might be true while quickly uninstalling the app from my phone. afterwards i checked and realised the app that i installed was an malware. I hope it would be fine after I uninstalled the app.

column1: At 13:28PM on 8 March 2021 I received a phonecall with number +6594999183 that had an automated voice recording informing me that I have been unresponsive to DBS bank trying to contact me several times and instructed me to dial '3' to speak to a staff member. I proceeded to do so and was responded by a man's voice saying "Hello DBS bank.." in a very low and slurred tone. I responded with "Hello.." and before I could say anything else the call was hung up. Only then that I realized that it was an unusual circumstance and proceeded to locate a scam call hotline and made a police report.

I received a phonecall at 11.55am on 8 March. the indian man claims that he is from singtel technical department and claims that my name cannot be found in their list. i do not have any subscriptions with singtel before so i detected it as a scam which i hung up immediately.
I had a call on 5th march at 11.57 am From a Filipino sOunding man who cLaimed that he‚Äôs from DBS. He said my account has been suspended and Wanted my account number and I/C. Luckily
column2: I was already aware of the scams Via media and was rather annoyed at how NONCHALANT this caller is using DBS banks name For scamming. I told him ‚Äú i‚Äôll report yoU to the police. You are Scammer." He stayed on the line for a while and hung up.

column1: I got a call at about 8:40am and picked up the call. I heard there was a robotic voice claiming that the caller was from "DBS" and that i never picked up their "calls many times" despite them never calling me in the first place. When i heard that i have to contact their "customer support"
column2: I immediately hung up. This followed by 2 more separate calls (both in different numbers
column3: +65 9108 8199 and +65 9834 8227) in the span of 18 minutes before not receiving more of these calls. I double-checked if the phone number i picked up was a scam call and i was so glad i did not pick up the other 2 phone calls as i found out that phone numbers with the "+65" prefix could be a spoofed calls.

Editor's Note: Please note that unlicensed moneylenders or loan scammers can impersonate licensed moneylenders to cheat. They could set up fake website
column2: misuse the licensed moneylender's company's name and licence number to fool the public. To prevent falling prey to such scams
column3: do not respond to online advertisements promoting moneylending services. Licensed moneylenders are not allowed to promote or advertise their services on social media such as Facebook
column4: SMS
column5: or Whatsapp or via Google advertisements. Please only get in touch with licensed moneylenders via the contact details found in this list: MLs listing as at 01Feb2021 - updated.pdf (mlaw.gov.sg)
column6: including checking the URL of the website that you are visiting against this list. If the address of the website that you are visiting doesn't correspond with the one shown in the attached list

column1: I have received an email supposedly from Singapore post saying that they noticed a delivery on hold due to non-payment of S$2.10 last week. they requested me to make payment of S$2.10 in order to receive the delivery. I ignored it because of the suspicious email address. then I received the email from the same email address again on 25 Feb 2021. I felt that i have to alert someone about it

column1: I recently lost my job and was desperate for rent money and I was stressed to not have a place to stay. I found "Kim En? Finance" on Facebook filled up to apply. The next morning a person call Kim En? message me via WhatsApp. Asked for my payslip and IC after sending me a photo of his name card I also double check the list of money lenders. I asked for a 2000 loan he told me I needed to send 250 a month upfront to indicate I can make monthly payments. I agree he send all a contract. I send the 250 and he then message and send a message after due to you sending the bank needs a validation fee to send the money. I got suspicious and he send a fake OUB screenshot. The next day I send 250. A manager call me and said MAs required a fee of 300 to immediate transfer. It was than it hit me that this was a scam a email send also had MAS logo on it but learn after contacting MAS that it was a fake. I than proceeded to make a police report and that company became uncontactable.

1) This happened to my helper. My heper got to know a man by the name of aisha muhammad from facebook. They have been chatting for 3 weeks. He has expressed interest in my helper and claimed that he wants to come to singapore to marry her. He said that he is sending gifts from London to Singapore and needs my helper to remit sgd500 to the courier company for her to receive the gifts. He claimed that he is divorced and has 2 daughters. He even had a video call once with my helper. But after much questioning from me and probing of information from the voice messages sent
column2: the voice of the man has an accent that doesn't sound like he is from London and his command of English seems to be quite bad. My helper has shared part of my address (excluding my unit) number with him and has even told him that she works at my place and disclosed how many people are at home. 2) happened today 26 feb 21 around sgt 5pm. This was the time my helper asked me to remit her salary to another account.3) money was not lost. The only thing lost was her disclosure of part of my address to the scammer

column1: I did some online shopping and was expecting to receive some packages. I received this email
